So truth to be told, I don't think the hearings have revealed anything very deep about where Judge Alito stands, but by the same token I don't think the senators have put him in a place where he would have had to reveal that.
Well, tell me a little bit about the genesis of this process.
Seems to me there was a time when the point was to see whether a candidate was qualified.
The ideological test was clear.
If the president wanted this person, they were in the president's camp.
That had been taken for granted at one point, wasn't it?
And that wasn't part of this process.
It was simply qualifications and whether or not, you know, corruption was part of it.
Well, the history's a little more complicated than that.
I think in the early years of the republic, politics played an enormous role in people's thinking about who should make it onto the Supreme Court.
But the actual idea that there would be a conformation hearing at which the nominee himself or herself would appear and answer questions is actually a much more modern phenomenon.
Well into the 20th century, the nominee didn't even appear in front of the Senate.

Sometimes a nominee would just send a representative over to the Legislature to answer questions, and at other times nobody would appear at all, and the debate would take place in the candidate's absence.
But in the sort of post-war era, it became increasingly common for nominees to show up.

And I think with the hearings for Judge Robert Bork, we got the sort of highest point of debate where there was actually substantive, detailed debate about the nominee's actual constitutional views which he, to his credit, very forthrightly put on the table.
And is that the role of the Senate in this process?
That's a question for serious controversy.
All the Constitution says is that the president nominates the nominee, and the nominee is confirmed with the advice and consent of the Senate.

So it's up to each senator to decide what he or she thinks the words advice and consent mean, and all we can go by is historical practice, and as I just suggested, the historical practice has changed a lot over time.
Why did it change?
Why did candidates suddenly start showing up?
Or, maybe the other way, why did they not come, you know, before, say, 50 years ago?
Probably it has a lot to do with the increased politicization of the nominations process.

And as the question of who's going to be on the Supreme Court has increasingly been a question of national importance that ordinary people all over the country cared about, that's become more and more central.

That in turn is connected to the rise of a judiciary that actually does a lot, a court that actually intervenes frequently in overturning either laws that Congress passed or laws that the states have passed.
And that's really been going on for most of this century.
And there were very controversial Supreme Court nominations even early in the century.

When Justice Brandeis was nominated to the court, there was tremendous opposition, partly anti-Semitic opposition, but also partly opposition couched in the idea that he was a friend of the laboring man and that he would stand for the interests of common people.
And that was considered problematic by some of the business interests.
So far what has been the most contentious issue or what--most contentious issues do you think for Judge Alito?

How much power does the president have?

The reason that it's significant is that's in the news as a central issue in our constitutional balance of powers.

Since we've got a president who's gone very far in terms of demanding greater executive power and with the recent news of the eavesdropping on conversations of US persons, apparently in violation of at least the text of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, we've got more discussions of presidential power.

I'm always curious about this kind of questioning where you try to get at the candidate's or the nominee's ideology.

They can.

Judge Alito several times said that he would use a framework for consideration that's called the Youngstown framework, named for the steel seizure case in which the Supreme Court overturned President Truman's attempts to nationalize the steel mills during the Korea War.
And he said that he would use a particular opinion, Justice Jackson's concurrence, in that case, which evaluates how you should think about the question of presidential power vis-a-vis Congress.

And in so saying, Judge Alito was signaling, perhaps subtly but he was signaling, that he didn't have the view that the president could always do whatever he wanted subject to a constitutional right to act in a certain area but that Congress had some say in the process as well.
So that was, I think, a significant thing for him to do, and I think it gave some indication--not a definitive one, but some indication--of how he might at least think about those kind of problems.

Someone like Judge Bork, who had a long career of distinguished scholarship in constitutional law, would be very hard to get past this kind of controversial world nowadays, I think.

The phrase `unitary executive' literally just means that in the Constitution, the entire executive power is given to the president.
And that means, according to those advocates with this view, that Congress or the courts can't horn in on the president when he's exercising the powers that the Constitution gives to him.
Now on one level, that's completely unproblematic.

Everyone who's studied the Constitution would agree that the Constitution says that the executive power goes to the president, and that means it doesn't go to Congress and it doesn't go to the courts.
But often the phrase `unitary executive' has been used to mean that Congress can't do anything to limit the president when he's exercising his powers.
So, for example, there's no question out of the Constitution that the president is commander in chief, but what may Congress do to guide him in how he exercises his power in that way?

Some advocates of the `unitary executive' theory would say that, for example, if the president needs to torture people as part of his constitutional duty to win a war, that Congress can't stop him from doing so, so that even if the law were passed by Congress, which, in fact, it hasn't passed, saying that you can't torture people, the president could still torture those people regarding--ignoring what Congress said because the Constitution entitles him to fight our wars as commander in chief.
Some people might say with respect to surveillance, the Constitution says the president can engage in our foreign policy.
Well, maybe foreign policy involves eavesdropping on foreign agents.
And so even if Congress says the president can't do that, then in theory he's still able to eavesdrop.
